family.name: dc
family.label: Dublin Core
family.description:
The Dublin Coreâ„¢ Metadata Initiative, or "DCMI", is an organization supporting innovation in metadata design and best practices across the metadata ecology. DCMI works openly, and it is supported by a paid-membership model.
The tags in this family correspond to the dc/elements/1.1 namespace, originally created in 2000 for the RDF representation of the fifteen-element Dublin Core and widely used in data for more than twenty years.

tag.name: Title
tag.label: Title
tag.description: A name given to the resource.

format.description: Recommended practice is to refer to the subject with a URI. If this is not possible or feasible, a literal entry that identifies the subject may be provided. Both should preferably refer to a subject in a controlled vocabulary.

tag.name: Creator
tag.label: Creator
tag.description: An entity responsible for making the resource.

format.description: Recommended practice is to identify the creator with a URI. If this is not possible or feasible, a literal entry that identifies the creator may be provided.

tag.name: Contributor
tag.label: Contributor
tag.description: An entity responsible for making contributions to the resource.

format.description: The guidelines for using names of persons or organizations as creators apply to contributors. Recommended practice is to identify the creator with a URI. If this is not possible or feasible, a literal entry that identifies the creator may be provided.

tag.name: Publisher
tag.label: Publisher
tag.description: An entity responsible for making the resource available.

tag.name: Date
tag.label: Date
tag.description: A point or period of time associated with an event in the lifecycle of the resource. Date may be used to express temporal information at any level of granularity.

format.description: Recommended practice is to express the date, date/time, or period of time according to ISO 8601-1 or a published profile of the ISO standard, such as the W3C Note on Date and Time Formats or the Extended Date/Time Format Specification. If the full date is unknown, month and year (YYYY-MM) or just year (YYYY) may be used. Date ranges may be specified using ISO 8601 period of time specification in which start and end dates are separated by a '/' (slash) character. Either the start or end date may be missing.

tag.name: Description
tag.label: Description
tag.description: An account of the resource. Description may include but is not limited to: an abstract, a table of contents, a graphical representation, or a free-text account of the resource.

tag.name: Type
tag.label: Type
tag.description: The nature or genre of the resource.

format.description: Recommended practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the DCMI Type Vocabulary (see examples). To describe the file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource, use the property Format.

tag.name: Format
tag.label: Format
tag.description: The file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource.

format.description: Recommended practice is to use a controlled vocabulary where available. For example, for file formats one could use the list of Internet Media Types. Examples of dimensions include size and duration.

Recommended practice is to use either a non-literal entry representing a language from a controlled vocabulary such as ISO 639-2 or ISO 639-3, or a literal entry consisting of an IETF Best Current Practice 47 language tag.

tag.name: Coverage
tag.label: Coverage
tag.description: The spatial or temporal topic of the resource, spatial applicability of the resource, or jurisdiction under which the resource is relevant. Spatial topic and spatial applicability may be a named place or a location specified by its geographic coordinates. Temporal topic may be a named period, date, or date range. A jurisdiction may be a named administrative entity or a geographic place to which the resource applies.

format.description: Recommended practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names. Where appropriate, named places or time periods may be used in preference to numeric identifiers such as sets of coordinates or date ranges.

tag.name: Identifier
tag.label: Identifier
tag.description: An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.

format.description: Recommended practice is to identify the resource by means of a string conforming to an identification system. Examples include International Standard Book Number (ISBN), Digital Object Identifier (DOI), and Uniform Resource Name (URN). Persistent identifiers should be provided as HTTP URIs.

tag.name: Source
tag.label: Source
tag.description: A related resource from which the described resource is derived. This property is intended to be used with non-literal values. The described resource may be derived from the related resource in whole or in part.

format.description: Best practice is to identify the related resource by means of a URI or a string conforming to a formal identification system.
Recommended practice is to identify the related resource by means of a URI. If this is not possible or feasible, a string conforming to a formal identification system may be provided.

tag.name: Rights
tag.label: Rights
tag.description: Information about rights held in and over the resource. Typically, rights information includes a statement about various property rights associated with the resource, including intellectual property rights.

format.description: Recommended practice is to refer to a rights statement with a URI. If this is not possible or feasible, a literal entry (name, label, or short text) may be provided.
